conclusion: Understanding the ion implantation process in chip manufacturing.
Ions are accelerated from the ion source and enter the velocity selector horizontally.
The velocity selector has both electric and magnetic fields.
The electric field is directed vertically upwards, and the magnetic field is directed outward perpendicular to the paper, both with magnitudes E and B, respectively.

premise: In the velocity selector, the electric force on the ion is qE (upward), and the magnetic force is qvB (downward).
conclusion: For the ion to pass through straightly, these forces should balance: qE = qvB
Only ions with this velocity will pass through the selector without being deflected.
Ions enter the magnetic analyzer, which is a quarter-circular ring with inner radius R1 and outer radius R2.
The magnetic field in the magnetic analyzer is also B, outward perpendicular to the paper.

premise: The path of the ion in the magnetic field is a circle with radius R given by: mv²/R = qvB
Since the ions have passed the velocity selector with v = E/B, we can substitute v: R = m(E/B)/q(B) = mE/qB²

conclusion: In the magnetic analyzer, the path is a quarter-circle from M to N.

premise: The radii R1 and R2 might be used to select ions within a certain range of masses or charges.
conclusion: The magnetic analyzer selects ions based on charge-to-mass ratio.
Ions enter the deflection system, which also has electric and magnetic fields.
In the deflection system, the electric field is directed outward perpendicular to the paper, and the magnetic field is directed vertically upwards, both with magnitudes E and B, respectively.
In the deflection system, the fields are in the same cube with side length L, and the bottom of the cube is L units above the wafer.
When no fields are applied in the deflection system, ions are injected vertically onto point O on the wafer.
